pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:0.5.eng: 9. The second training rule on what is set aside

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro puriso aññataraṃ purisaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.2.eng: a certain man said to another man,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.3.eng: “I’m going to give robe-cloth to Venerable Upananda.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.6.pli: Assosi kho aññataro piṇḍacāriko bhikkhu tesaṃ purisānaṃ imaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.6.eng: An alms-collecting monk heard that conversation.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.7.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu yenāyasmā upanando sakyaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.7.eng: He then went to Upananda the Sakyan and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.9.pli: Amukasmiṃ okāse aññataro puriso aññataraṃ purisaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.9.eng: In such-and-such a place I heard two men telling each other

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.10.eng: that they’re each going to give you robe-cloth.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.14.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto yena te purisā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te purise etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.14.eng: Upananda then went to those men and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.15.pli: “saccaṃ kira maṃ tumhe, āvuso, cīvarehi acchādetukāmātthā”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.15.eng: “Is it true that you want to give me robe-cloth?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.17.eng: that’s just what we were thinking.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.18.pli: “Sace kho maṃ tumhe, āvuso, cīvarehi acchādetukāmāttha, evarūpena cīvarena acchādetha,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.18.eng: “If that’s the case, then give me such-and-such robe-cloth.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.19.pli: kyāhaṃ tehi acchannopi karissāmi, yānāhaṃ na paribhuñjissāmī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.19.eng: For what’s the point of giving robe-cloth that I won’t use?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.20.pli: Atha kho te purisā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.20.eng: Those men complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.21.eng: “These Sakyan monastics have great desires. They’re not content.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.22.eng: It’s no easy matter to give them robe-cloth.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.23.pli: Kathañhi nāma ayyo upanando amhehi pubbe appavārito upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjissatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.23.eng: How could Venerable Upananda come to us and say what kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited by us to do so?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.24.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ purisānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.24.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those men,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.25.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.25.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.26.pli: “kathañhi nāma āyasmā upanando sakyaputto pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjissatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.26.eng: “How could Venerable Upananda go to householders and say what kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited to do so?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.27.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.27.eng: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.28.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, upananda, pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjasī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.28.eng: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.32.pli: “Aññātako, moghapurisa, aññātakānaṃ na jānāti patirūpaṃ vā appatirūpaṃ vā santaṃ vā asantaṃ vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.32.eng: “Foolish man, people who are unrelated don’t know what’s appropriate and inappropriate, what’s good and bad, in dealing with each other.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.33.pli: Tattha nāma tvaṃ, moghapurisa, pubbe appavārito aññātake gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjissasi.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.35.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.35.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.36.1.pli: “Bhikkhuṃ paneva uddissa ubhinnaṃ aññātakānaṃ gahapatīnaṃ vā gahapatānīnaṃ vā paccekacīvaracetāpannāni upakkhaṭāni honti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.36.1.eng: ‘If two male or female householders have set aside separate robe funds for an unrelated monk, thinking,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.37.pli: ‘imehi mayaṃ paccekacīvaracetāpannehi paccekacīvarāni cetāpetvā itthannāmaṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvarehi acchādessāmā’ti;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.37.eng: “With these separate robe funds we’ll buy separate robe-cloths and give them to monk so-and-so;”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.38.pli: tatra ce so bhikkhu pubbe appavārito upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjeyya—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.38.eng: and if that monk, without first being invited, goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.39.pli: ‘sādhu vata maṃ āyasmanto imehi paccekacīvaracetāpannehi evarūpaṃ vā evarūpaṃ vā cīvaraṃ cetāpetvā acchādetha, ubhova santā ekenā’ti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.39.eng: “Please put these separate robe funds together to buy such-and-such robe-cloth and then give it to me,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.39.comm: The phrase ubhova santā ekena, here translated as “put together”, is not immediately clear. It seems to me that this phrase needs to be related to the main sentence verb acchādetha, “present” or “give”, which takes the instrumental of the thing given: “present (him) with one (robe)”. Ubhova santā is explained below in the word commentary as dvepi janā, “both people”, and the overall phrase then becomes, “two people present (him) with one (robe)”. This means that the funds are put together, and I translate accordingly.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:1.40.eng: and he does so because he wants something fine, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.2.pli: bhikkhussatthāya, bhikkhuṃ ārammaṇaṃ karitvā, bhikkhuṃ acchādetukāmā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.2.eng: for the benefit of a monk; making a monk the object of consideration, they want to give to him.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.6.pli: mātito vā pitito vā yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā asambaddhā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.6.eng: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back eight generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.6.comm: Sp 1.505: Tattha yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti pitupitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṁ pitāmahayugaṁ, “In this yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means: the father of a father is a grandfather. The generation of a grandfather is called a pitāmahayuga.” So the PaIi phrase yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means “as far as the seventh generation of grandfathers”, that is, eight generations back. This can be counted as follows: (1) one’s grandfather; (2) his father; (3) 2’s father; (4) 3’s father; (5) 4’s father; (6) 5’s father; and (7) 6’s father. This applies to both one’s paternal and maternal grandfathers. This gives a total of 14 ancestors. Anyone who is a descendent of these fourteen is considered a relative. Anyone who is not such a descendent is not regarded as a relative.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.8.eng: any men who live at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.8.comm: Agāraṁ is typically rendered as “in a house”. The problem with this is that it is not unallowable for a monastic to live in a building that is the equivalent of a house. What a monastic should not do is own a home and then live there.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.10.eng: any women who live at home.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.12.pli: hiraññā vā suvaṇṇā vā muttā vā maṇī vā pavāḷā vā phalikā vā paṭakā vā suttā vā kappāsā vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.12.eng: money, gold, pearls, gems, corals, crystals, cloth, thread, or cotton wool.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.14.eng: with that which is at their disposal.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.20.pli: yaṃ bhikkhuṃ uddissa cīvaracetāpannāni upakkhaṭāni honti so bhikkhu.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.20.eng: the monk the robe funds have been set aside for.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.22.pli: pubbe avutto hoti— “kīdisena te, bhante, cīvarena attho, kīdisaṃ te cīvaraṃ cetāpemā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.22.eng: they have not said beforehand: “Venerable, what kind of robe-cloth do you need? What kind of robe-cloth can we buy for you?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.24.eng: having gone to their house or having gone wherever.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.25.eng: Specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.26.pli: āyataṃ vā hotu vitthataṃ vā appitaṃ vā saṇhaṃ vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.26.eng: please make it long or wide or closely woven or soft.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.28.eng: that which is at their disposal.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.30.pli: āyataṃ vā vitthataṃ vā appitaṃ vā saṇhaṃ vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.30.eng: long or wide or closely woven or soft.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.36.eng: two people supplying him with one robe-cloth.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.38.eng: wanting something good, wanting something expensive.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.39.pli: Tassa vacanena āyataṃ vā vitthataṃ vā appitaṃ vā saṇhaṃ vā cetāpenti, payoge dukkaṭaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.39.eng: If those householders buy robe-cloth that is long, wide, closely woven, or soft because of his statement, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.40.eng: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.41.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.41.eng: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.42.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.43.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.44.pli: “idaṃ me, bhante, cīvaraṃ pubbe appavārito aññātake gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpannaṃ nissaggiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.44.eng: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I received after going to unrelated householders and saying what kind of robe-cloth I wanted without first being invited, is to be relinquished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.45.eng: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.48.eng: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.49.1.pli: Aññātake aññātakasaññī pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.49.1.eng: If the householders are unrelated and he perceives them as such, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.50.pli: Aññātake vematiko pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.50.eng: If the householders are unrelated, but he is unsure of it, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.51.pli: Aññātake ñātakasaññī pubbe appavārito gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.51.eng: If the householders are unrelated, but he perceives them as related, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.52.eng: If the householders are related, but he perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.53.eng: If the householders are related, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.54.eng: If the householders are related and he perceives them as such, there is no offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.57.eng: if it is from those who have given an invitation;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.58.eng: if it is for the benefit of another;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.59.eng: if it is by means of his own property;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.60.eng: if the householders wish to buy something expensive, but he has them buy something inexpensive;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.62.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np9:2.63.eng: The second training rule on what is set aside, the ninth, is finished.
